q: September 5, 2002 Report Shaffer wrote on September 5, 2002 that he had been asked by Donald Rumsfeld what the U.S. did not know in terms of percentage about Iraq's WMD program. We've struggled to estimate unknowns, and the attached briefing sumps up our best J2 sense, he said. J2 is an intelligence group supporting top level U.S. defense officials.`` We range from 0% to about 75% knowledge on various aspects of their program,'' he said.

Announcing the plan at a conference in Munich yesterday( 25 January), outgoing chief executive Eric Schmidt says: We looked at this year and our prospects for growth in Europe, and our businesses globally are doing well, both our core business and our adjacent businesses. has 25 touchdown passes and just five interceptions on third down.`` Aaron Rodgers 's a special athlete,'' Green Bay coach Mike McCarthy said after the Packers defeated Chicago 21-14 in the NFC championship game. He can do everything you want at the quarterback position. Can make all the throws. Very smart. Has great command of the quarterback position. And he can run. Meanwhile, Sergio Marchionne also said Fiat will not consider selling its Alfa Romeo brand to Volkswagen AG. VW Chairman Ferdinand Piech has indicated an interest in buying Alfa from Fiat Group. But Sergio Marchionne said: As long as I am CEO of Chrysler and Fiat, Mr. Ferdinand Piech will never have Alfa Romeo. It's hands-off. I told him. I will call him and I will e-mail him. The idea that he was lying or duped is nonsense, Donald Rumsfeld added. Donald Rumsfeld said`` it's possible'' that decisions on troop levels in Iraq may have been the biggest mistake of the war. He maintained that the war overall was not a mistake.
